Two years today since we 
reached Mar
 landed in Marsalles & if anyone had told us then that the war would still be as desperate as ever we should have laughed at the possibility & yet the Germans are making their greatest effort & have regained all the ground they lost in the Somme Fighting of 1916-7

We are still up near Ypres which is quite quiet after last years Autumn Fighting though I expect we are pretty sure to go south soon to relieve some 
of the
 Division down there.

One effect of the German Advance has been to stop all the 'peace-grousing'

that goes on for lack of any other subject & it has had the same effect in the old country to automatically settle all strikes & trade disputes

We reached our camp that evening about 6 p.m. & as Fritz was not too far away we were issued with extra ammunition & we fully expected a call out that night. But it did not come & yesterday we moved again – we were ready by 10 a.m. but did not eventually move off until 1 p.m. making towards Sercus – we were halted for some time about 1 kilo from the latter place at a crossroads just the 4 waggons in charge of the Sgt. – When the Sgt drew our attention to a man dressed as an officer standing at the X roads with a map in his hand having a good look

We saw the Sgt stop him & make enquiries & not evidently being satisfied brought him back

Entry.12:
Still camped on the outskirts of Sylvestre Cappel – have nothing to write about just waiting (that is what we all feel) for Fritz's next big effort. We are having moonlight nights & Fritz is doing a lot of night bombing round about here – varied with long distance shelling – he put half a dozen big shrapnel over the village last night.

From a small party, some 12 of them – German prisoners brought down a week ago I got a ration of their army bread. Black, sodden looking & most unpalatable stuff

imaginable – & when one thinks that the army gets the best of their food – one wonders what the Civilian Bread is like.

Nine of the dozen were mere lads, they claimed to be 19 but hardly looked it & had evidently only just joined up their regiments from the depot by the look of their uniforms

I have just heard that my name has been sent in to Headquarters amongst others for a furlough to Australia I can hardly realize the possibility after nearly 4 years now of this life. When my

turn will come – I have no idea but it is something to be "on the list"

Very hot weather this last few days & the country is looking lovely

Colombo –
arrived here yesterday morning after a very smooth journey. We got leave

ashore for a few hours – Went ashore in lighters & then marched up to the Barracks two or 3 hundred yards from the wharf where the YMCA had some dinner ready for us – a 
ramb
 rickshaw ride & ramble round the shops in the afternoon & the ladies of Colombo gave us all tea at the YM in in afternoon – I had to be back on board by 5 p.m. as I was on guard that night.
